Problem:
Examine the complex function \( z(t) = x(t) + i y(t) \) where \( x(t) \) and \( y(t) \) are solutions to the coupled differential equations \( \dot{x} = Ax + By \) and \( \dot{y} = Cx + Dy \) respectively. Consider the effect of the linear operator \( L(z) = e^{Mt}z \) where M is a constant matrix, applied at different intervals.

If \( L(z) \) is applied to a complex number \( z_0 \) at t = 0, and then the system evolves according to \( \dot{x} \) and \( \dot{y} \) without further intervention, will \( z(T) \) at T be the same as if \( z_0 \) was directly evolved to T under \( \dot{x} \) and \( \dot{y} \)?
Explanation: The initial application of \( L(z) \) changes the complex number, affecting how it evolves under the differential equations. The transformation by \( e^{Mt} \) can alter both magnitude and phase, leading to a different position in the complex plane at time T.
